content.webTitle: David Speers won't start at ABC until 2020 after Sky insists he serve out contract

fields.headline: David Speers won't start at ABC until 2020 after Sky insists he serve out contract
fields.bodyText: The ABC has confirmed David Speers will join the public broadcaster to host Insiders – but not until 2020 as Sky News has insisted he work out the remainder of his contract. Almost two weeks after Guardian Australia revealed the political journalist had accepted an offer to join the ABC to replace Barrie Cassidy, Sky News broke its silence and admitted Speers had resigned. Sky News chief executive officer Paul Whittaker said Speers would continue on-air as political editor and anchor of Speers and Speers on Sunday until the end of his contract early next year. “David is an exceptional and highly respected journalist and one of Australia’s most insightful political interviewers,” Whittaker said. “His highly decorated career has seen him chosen to host leaders’ debates and forums at the last six federal elections, as well as cover the last four US presidential elections.” The ABC welcomed Speers and said its journalists Annabel Crabb and Fran Kelly would fill in for him on Insiders for the remainder of the year. Cassidy’s farewell show is on Sunday 9 June. Speers, who has remained silent on his defection until now, revealed he never missed an episode of Insiders. “Insiders is essential viewing if you’re interested in politics and understanding how Australia is being led,” Speers said. “I never miss it. To be able to take over from a legend, Barrie Cassidy, and present the program is an honour and a terrific opportunity.” Speers, who lives in Canberra, will move to Melbourne where the program is produced and will work with executive producer Sam Clark. ABC news director Gaven Morris said Speers was a worthy successor to Cassidy. “David is a terrific journalist and presenter, an astute political observer and a great talent,” Morris said. “He joins Australia’s best and most trusted political journalism team.” Whittaker said Speers had made an outstanding contribution to Australian journalism and Sky News and wished him well. The 44-year-old, who has won two Walkley Awards, an AACTA Subscription Television Award, a Kennedy Award and ten ASTRA Awards, is taking a pay cut of some $200,000 to join the ABC. He is the highest paid presenter at Rupert Murdoch’s pay TV operation, where sources say he is on $680,000. Widely admired for his razor-sharp interviews with politicians, Speers has managed to keep his reputation as a fair minded journalist despite being the face of the right-wing channel.
